article.description: Marquette didn't need a big game from Dwyane Wade to get back on the winning track.
article.headline: Golden Eagles show inside toughness in victory
article.linkText: Marquette returns to inside game, gets win over St. Louis
article.story: ST. LOUIS (AP) -- Marquette didn't need a big game from Dwyane Wade to get back on the winning track. Scott Merritt had 14 points and 11 rebounds as the Golden Eagles (No. 23 ESPN/USA Today, No. 24 AP), playing a dominating inside game that more than made up for Wade only scoring six points, held off Saint Louis 60-54 on Tuesday night. Marquette (9-3, 1-1 Conference USA) recovered from consecutive losses to Dayton and East Carolina that knocked the Golden Eagles down 11 spots in the poll. Marquette outrebounded Saint Louis (6-6, 0-1) 38-18, including 16-4 on the offensive end. "We wanted to try and go inside as much as possible anyway,'' Marquette coach Tom Crean said. "We're a little bit bigger and more skilled inside.'' The Golden Eagles had been outrebounding opponents by 4.5 per game. "We've not been happy with our rebounding,'' Crean said. "I think our players have been embarrassed about the way our rebounding has gone. "We have made a great commitment over the last week to be better at it; we've got to be if we want to win.'' Robert Jackson added 13 points and seven rebounds for Marquette, which won despite a meager contribution from Conference USA's leading scorer. Wade, who averages 24.2 points, missed his first five shots, missed part of the second half with bruised ribs and finished 3-for-10 in 29 minutes. Saint Louis players knew those numbers didn't count for much. "You can look at the stat sheet,'' forward Chris Braun said. "The rebound totals are atrocious.'' Coach Brad Soderberg took that a step farther. "Anytime you let a team get 16 offensive rebounds in a game that's only a 60-point game, that's suicidal,'' Soderberg said. Freshman reserve Steve Novak helped secure the victory by going 4-for-4 from the free throw line over the final 30 seconds. Novak, who averages 3.0 points and had been scoreless the previous two games, had 10 points, including two 3-pointers in the second half. "No nerves,'' Novak said. "I was ready when I got to the line.'' Marquette has won five in a row and six of seven against Saint Louis, which kept it close by shooting 46.5 percent. Marque Perry had 20 points, six rebounds and five assists for Saint Louis, which had won five straight at home. Josh Fisher added 16 points and four steals after being held to two points in each of his last two games. "Marque Perry is one of the toughest matchups not only in our league but any league,'' Crean said. "We'll be paying to watch him in those NBA arenas next year.'' The teams combined for only nine points over the final 10 minutes of the first half as Marquette took a 23-22 lead. The Golden Eagles went ahead 21-15 on a putback by Merritt with 9:47 left, but their only points until halftime came on an alley-oop dunk by Wade with 1:09 to go. Marquette led 53-44 on Jackson's layup with 4:21 left. Saint Louis scored six straight points to cut the deficit to three with 2:07 to play, but never got any closer.
